TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive Typic Haplocryepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Mine loam - forest.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--1 inch to 0; undecomposed organic material mainly needles, bark, and twigs.
A1--0 to 3 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) loam, very dark brown (10YR 2/2) moist; strong medium crumb structure; soft, very friable, nonsticky, nonplastic; 5 percent gravel; slightly acid (pH 6.1); gradual wavy boundary.  (1 to 4 inches thick)
AC--3 to 6 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) gravelly loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure that parts to fine granules; soft, very friable, nonsticky, nonplastic; 5 percent gravel; medium acid (pH 5.8); gradual wavy boundary.  (0 to 5 inches thick)
C--6 to 60 inches; light yellowish brown (2.5Y 6/3) gravelly sandy loam, light olive brown (2.5Y 5/3) moist; massive; soft, very friable, nonsticky, nonplastic; 5 percent gravel; medium acid (pH 5.8).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Grand County, Colorado; 50 feet west of the road and .1 mile north of Forest Service headquarters; in NE1/4 NE1/4, Sec. 4, T. 2 S., R. 76 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Depth to uniformly calcareous material ranges from 40 to more than 60 inches.  Although pH of some subhorizons is less than 5.5 (1:1 dilution in water) a major part of the control section between depths of 10 to 20 inches has pH exceeding 5.5 and is more than 60 percent base saturated.  The control section is usually sandy loam or gravelly sand loam but clay ranges from 5 to 18 percent, silt from 5 to 40 percent, and sand from 50 to 80 percent with more than 35 percent being fine or coarser sand.  Rock fragments range from 0 to 35 percent and are mainly 1/2 to 10 inches in diameter.  Subhorizons redder than 7.5YR are in some pedons but a major part of the control section above a depth of 40 inches has hue of 7.5YR or yellower.  These soils are dry in some part of the moisture control section in some time most years.
The A horizon has hue of 5Y through 7.5YR, value of 4 through 6 dry, 2 through 4 moist, and chroma of 1 through 4.  It ranges from strongly acid to slightly acid (1:5 dilution unbuffered organic dye).
The C horizon has hue of 5Y through 7.5YR.  Subhorizons redder than 7.5YR are in some pedons.  This horizon ranges from strongly acid to slightly acid (1:5 dilution unbuffered organic dye).

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Baldy, Bobtail, and Stecum series.  Baldy soils have a significant component of volcanic ash and have peak periods of precipitation in the late summer and winter months.  Bobtail soils have an albic horizon and a cambic horizon.  Stecum soils are sandy-skeletal.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Mine soils are on gently to steeply sloping outwash plains, alluvial fans, and valley side slopes.  Slopes typically range from about 2 to 20 percent or more.  The soil formed in thick moderately coarse textured noncalcareous transported material derived principally from gneiss, schist, and quartizite.  At the type location the mean annual precipitation is about 32 inches with peak periods of precipitation in the spring and early summer months.  Mean annual temperature is 30 degrees F. and mean summer temperature is 51 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the competing Bobtail soils and the Tabernash soils.  Tabernash soils have albic horizons, moderately fine textured argillic horizons, and sandy-skeletal IIC horizons.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; slow to very slow runoff; rapid to very rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Used principally as grazing land or for timber production.  Native vegetation is lodgepole pine, fir, spruce, and aspen with a weak understory of grasses and shrubs.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Central Colorado.  The series is of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Frazer Alpine Area, Colorado, 1957.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Differentiation between the Baldy and Mine series needs more work.  Last updated by the state 4/73.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
